segments.text: Interview with Dr. W. W. Rostow, aide to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, May 2, 1986, LBJ Library.
Testing, one, two, three.
Actually, having this close is pretty, it would be really close from the room.
All right.
In U.S. News and World Report, you stated that Hanoi built its policy on the judgment that the U.S. could not stand a long, indecisive war.
and that Washington built its policy on faith in the reality of South Vietnamese and Southeast Asian nationalism.
And I'm curious what faith you're speaking of, and I would like this sort of in two parts.
In 1961, when President Kennedy increased the number of advisors, and then in 1965, when we committed ground forces.
What's your question?
You speak that we built our policy on the faith in the reality of South Vietnamese and Southeast Asian nationalism.
That's correct.
And I'm curious what nationalism you speak of.
I'm talking about the nationalism of the South Vietnamese, who wanted a destiny independent of Hanoi.
That was the central question that President Kennedy asked me to investigate, as I reported, when I went out with General Taylor.
And before he made up his mind, he
committed himself to the defense of South Vietnam under the Southeast Asian Treaty.
He explored all the evidence he could that the South Vietnamese did not wish to go with the North.
And as I say, that was the central question he asked me, aside from being number two in that mission, to investigate.
And I describe how I did it in the Diffusion of Power, and I recorded it here.
But he based his
his policy on the answer, as indeed did President Johnson.
And there's no doubt that there was, and is to this day, a very strong South Vietnamese nationalism.
These people did not wish to go under the North, and they still haven't accepted rule from the North.
The North has been ruling the South through a carpetbagger administration.
There's a convention.
The conventional wisdom in a number of writers is that nationalism was on the side of the
and that there was no South Vietnamese nationalism.
That's just not true.

I know there's a difference because we've discussed the Chinese influence and the Indian influence on the South and the Chinese influence on the North and how there's really two different people almost.
Well, it's three different people, and that's one of the great illusions.
They have the same language, but there's a delta.
There's central Vietnam from which both Ho Chi Minh and Jim came, and then there's the Red River Valley people.
And they have, they never, you know, had a really truly united existence, and they have very distinct regionalized.
And the history of the whole post-colonial period has tragically, instead of bringing them together, heightened those tensions which are deep in their history.
Well, I have another question with that.
When I think of nationalism, I think of unity of a people that are willing to work towards a goal.
And in South Vietnam, you find a people that are, you know, you have a Catholic leader at first, leading Buddhists.
And as you reported in your book, in fact, in your report, the Rostow-Taylor report, you said that some of the people really just didn't care
who ruled them, they just wanted to be left alone and grow their rice.
Well, the point about it is you've got to understand what a little post-colonial country is.
They wanted toin most developing countries, which have not had a long history of national experience, you will find that the ties of clan, tribe in Africa,
of region are much stronger than the ties of nation, which are rather abstract.
What bound these people right to the end, and right down to the present time, is they did not wish to be run by the North.
And they also were united in an extraordinary way for
country at that stage in its history in a desire to be independent of the North politically, and they fought.

It used to shock students when I used to sit and talk with them about this, and it'll shock you no doubt, but they were much more united in their struggle against the North than we were against the British in the War of Independence.
Maybe one-third of the Americans were for independence, one-third were pro-British,
The third were out to make a fast buck selling stuff to the Army or out to lunch.
These people, when they went into the Army, there was no one-year hitch.
They'd be carried out in a plastic bag or wounded.
And at the time of Tet, if you passed out a million guns, he knew which way they were going to shoot.
He wasn't worried.
That was not the problem.
Well, if I could play devil's advocate here for a second.
Battle of Atpak in January 1963.
The Arvin clearly outnumbered the VC, and yet they threw their guns down and they ran.
There were occasions when they were outflanked or they ran, but on the whole they were very uneven.
They were a much more advanced army Than we give them credit for?
than the Koreans were at the equivalent period.
We couldn't do what we did in Korea.
It might have been in some way better, but they were much better organized and much more competent.
They had, we just integrated the units.
And some Korea, it was very good for the Korean training, but it was not good for institutionally.
These people had their separate units, and there was a wide range of competence in those units.
I remember when General Abrams came back after Tet, he went through all the major units and, you know, gave them, like a professor, he gave them the grades.
And there was a considerable range.
And, you know, they had some units who, the first division, I think, was one of the, it was as good as any American division.
Others were mediocre.
And the quality of the leadership, but you see, you've got to understand what a little post-colonial country's like.
It takes time.
I mean, your question, you see, revealed that you hadn't given enough thought.
My notion of nationalism is they want a country.
I mean, they're all united around a common purpose.
Well, they weren't.
They had much more unity, as I say, than we did at an equivalent time in our history.
But they had all sorts of divisions.
And the one thing that overwhelmingly united them was that they didn't want to be run from the North.
But it went on.
I'll tell you one.
You want to go back, if you're interested in learning about this and not simply repeating cliches and being devil's advocate.
Study sometime the elections of 1967.
And a very good team was sent out by the president and the press.
And these people, I was there when they reported, and they were all people with an independent constituency.
That is to say, they were not beholden to the president at all.
A number of them were against his policy.
whatever.
But they threw themselves very seriously into that election, very moving.

So they were moving forward, and if we hadn't walked out on them, they'd be well on their way to beingthey have the basic vitality of the South Koreans, and they would have made an economic and social success in the place.
Okay.
Was Ho Chi Minh a communist or a nationalist, in your opinion?
He was proud to be a communist, very proud to be a communist.
He was in the Comintern apparatus since the First World War, and he was the first to tell you he's a communist.
Of course he's a communist.
That doesn't mean he wasn't a nationalist also, to some extent.
But he was part of thethey all have strands of nationalism in them.
But yes, he was a professional who rose up to be head of the Vietnamese Communist Party by knocking off some of his opposition members.
But, you know, there's no question he worked in Moscow.
He was in the commentary and all the rest of it.
Okay.
Could we have recognized him in 1945, though, when he declared independence?
He had a constitution based after ours.
He offered us the use of Cameron Bay to put an American military base in.
Who said that?
That was in the Pentagon Papers, I believe.
I don't remember ever reading that, and I don't believe he would do that.
He couldn't do that and maintain his relations with China and Russia.
He might have done it during the war, perhaps, or something like that.
But the point about it is,

he was a thoroughly professional communist and his pattern of action is just like the communists in Nicaragua or Cuba or China what was the pattern to organize a popular front and with all kinds of people to tell the peasants you want to get your land to work with the Catholic Church in opposition with the unions until he had power
Then, with the hardcore communists, he cleaned out the unions.
He cleaned out the church.
He didn't give the people a land.
He put them in collective farms.
Very pedestrian exercise in the takeover of power, right by the book.
And you do know, by this time, if you don't see it, I don't know when you're ever going to learn about it.
But this is what's been repeated over and over again.
Now, the question is, if China had decided that it was not going into
with the Soviet Union.

He might have tried to make, I think, separate terms with the United States, but China decided, for very good reasons, from a communist point of view, that they would be dishonest, faithless to their own duty to history.
Why?
Because it's written into communist doctrine out of the experience of the Soviets.
Communist Party came to power as a counter-revolution in the midst of the confusions of war.
The confusions and flexibility, if you like, revolutionary potential of a war is written into the training of every good communist as a time of opportunity.
And when Mao looked at the situation in Asia, what did he see?
He saw a very weak South Korea and America that had pulled its forces out.
He looked at Taiwan, a defeated dynasty as in the past, Chinese history, had gone to Formosa and was having very grave trouble with the people on Formosa.
It was palpable.
There was a guerrilla set up in the Philippines operating communists.

there was a communist party and there was fighting in Malaysia in Burma also it turned out in Indonesia and the Japanese occupation had destroyed the foundations for colonialism in Asia any good communist would say this is a great historical opportunity to move forward now if we tie up with the Americans we have to we can't go into
conduct guerrilla wars all over Asia because these are strategically going to be at the expense of the Americans.
And therefore, it's proper for us to join the one major country that shares our interest in the success of making the most of this period of dishevelment in Asia for our purposes.
And that's what happened.
They debated it in China, but they decided to lean to one side, even though Mao's relations with Stalin had been, and with Moscow generally, had been very poor.
But at a time like that, his overriding duty was to make the most of this post-war period, and they tried.
And they had guerrilla wars operating not only in Indochina, but the Philippines, Burma,
From their point of view, I find it wholly understandable.
Who controlled the fighting of the war, LBJ or the military?
You really haven't read much, have you?
Yes, sir, I have.
What answer did you get from your reading?
I would say that LBJ did.
In what sense?
Well, he picked all the spots for the bombing.
We've had pilots come into our, veterans come into our class and give lectures.
And there's one, in fact, said that if you went on a bombing mission, but along the way you saw a VC battalion or something like that, you couldn't stop and immediately go to that fighting.
You had to call back and then
that person would have to call back, and so on and so forth.
And then we've also discussed how there was no supreme commander in Vietnam, that Arvin had their own commanders.
We had our own commander, General Westmoreland, and he was under the admiral in Hawaii, who was under President Johnson.
No, he was under the Joint Chiefs.
No, the point about it is it's quite right that President Johnson had made a number of very fundamental decisions.
The first was that
which I disagreed, but his decision was that we would fight the war basically on the ground inside the boundary of Vietnam.
That is to say, we wouldn't go into the Laos corridors on the ground where I wanted to go, for example.
Or we wouldn't go into North Vietnam on the ground.
Secondly, he controlled, and that's general strategy in the war, he did control.
Two, he controlled the targets around Hanoi.
which were settled at the Tuesday lunch, and what he had was a set of questions.
The question was, one, what is the target and its military meaning?
What advantages do you get from hitting the target?
Two, how many men would we lose and how many plans?
Three, what would be likely civilian casualties?
Four, what are the possibilities of hitting a foreign ship or something?
And he would, the target list around Hanoi would come to him.
He did not interfere for good or ill.
He did not interfere with the use of air power inside Vietnam or in the Panhandle or in the Laos Carriers.
But the broad strategy of how the war would be fought
and where it would be fought, the orders of magnitude of men that we would put in there, and the equipment, and the targets around Hanoi.
These he kept under personal control.
Otherwise, I'd say Westmoreland really had a quite free hand within that broad strategy.
But the real operative center for military decision, except for those three exceptions, was the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Did you agree with search and destroy?
Did you think that was the way to use our ground forces in Vietnam?
That wasn't the only way we did use our ground forces.
The ground forces were much more complex.
See, this was a three-level war.
It was a general, it was a war of conventional forces without a fixed front against the North Vietnamese.
It was a war against the main force, VC units.
It was a quite different kind of war.
And then there were the, the, the, what you call authentic guerrilla operations, which are quite different now.
And the proportions of those three elements changed through time.
And it ended up being with the VC washed out after Tet.
Main force units, very weak.
And it was mainly a North, and by the
big battle of 72.
It was a, a North Vietnamese war against the, without a fixed front, conventional war.
61, I'd say it was overwhelmingly a guerrilla war.
And so you've got to track all three elements into it, and search and destroy is a, it's, it's a very, let me give you an example, different kinds of operations.
When we began to get some forces on the ground,
we went into some base areas where we'd never been before, which we didn't have the power to penetrate in an effective way.
We began to do that in 66, 67.
And what you would do is to go in there and engage the forces and go to the bases and try to capture documents and do all that kind of thing.
That's one kind of operation.
Another kind of operation
It would be quite different.
It would be when the North Vietnamese came across the border near Cambodia, for example.
Those are big units, and you knew that they might come to Dalat, or they might come to An Loc, or they might come to any number of places along there, Loc Ninh.
And you would preempt them.
You'd get helicopters and you'd go in and engage them and rough them up enough so that they'd have to go back and re-equip and wait for new men or something.
That would be a preemptive operation.
Under what's called search and destroy, there's a very wide range of different kind of operations.
My basic view and difference of policy was that
I felt that fighting the war from the inside was going to be very slow and costly for the people of Southeast Asia, our lives, for ourselves, American people, the world.
That the war depended upon the flow of men and supplies from North Vietnam.
The air power could impose a tax on that flow, but not interdicted.
But it could be interdicted on the ground.
two beefed-up U.S. divisions with plenty of air support.
And that's what I wanted to do.

You discussed that the air attacks diverted 83,000 MVA troops and how it afflicted attrition and all this, and yet the North Vietnamese and the VC matched every one of our troop increases, and they just kept coming.
They kept the pressure upon us.
So in hindsight, do you believe the bombing was effective as you first believed?
Well, I did never believe that the bombing itself was going to be decisive.
That's why I just told you something.
You didn't seem to take it in.

I said what I wanted to do was to put forces on the ground because the flow of supplies and the problem of handling those supplies was something where air power could impose attacks, but it couldn't stop them.
Now, you got that?
Yes, sir.
All right.
And, uh, I thought it was, you know, not sufficient.

And, uh, uh, the, uh, so that I, that's why I did not think that air power could be used decisively and that, but that ground forces could be used decisively by going into Laos on the ground and, and interacting with Ho Chi Minh trails, which is not one trail, it's an area.
and I thought that could be done and should have been done.
Besides, I had other disagreements with the way air power was used.
I thought it was used very well atwhat's that base?
Denae?
No, no, no, during Tet Offensive, that place up near the border.
What's the name of the very famous place?
Quezon?
Quezon.
It was used very well under General Mollmeyer.
We began to have
I really worked out in that period the first really good use, I mean effective use, of the tactical air in the Laos corridors in southern North Vietnam.
But it was very hard to do because the flow of supplies was limited.
So I don't think air power was used
maximally, but a maximum use of it couldn't have been decisive, in my judgment, had it acted on the ground.
But your other assumption is they didn'tit wasn't a question of their matching.
What they did in North Vietnam was towhat they saw was the gradual attenuation, 66, 67, 68, 69, of the South Vietnamese forces
And they put in in 72 a truly maximum effort at that time, after we had withdrawn our ground forces.
And they were beaten, a fact which no one ever seems to mention anymore.
And that's how we got the truth.
And I think without Watergate, they were lived by that truth.
Did you read the account of the victorious North Vietnamese general in 75, of why they went in in 75?
Yes, sir, I was going to ask you that.
Well, you fellas don't do any homework.
You just come up with the same old cliches that all the kids had in the 60s, and you really ought to learn more.
You're not in the 60s.
You're a new generation.
I'm sorry, I read that in your, how you were irritated by certain questions being asked.
I'm not irritated by them.

I'm justno, but, you know, I don'tI spent more time with students, but I'm justwhat makes me sad, generally going around the country, when I talk to students, they don't come up with the same oldthey want to know what happened.
And I spent, you know, these talks with students, never less than three, usually five or six
Here is the document you ought to get, our great spring victory in account of the liberation of South Vietnam by General Van Tien Dung, chief of staff of the Vietnam People's Army.
This is his account of the circumstances that led him to go in.
It's summarized in the New York Times of April 26, 1976.
And all I'm going to do now isbut he gives a very vivid account of the effects of the
of the cuts of aid to the VietnameseSouth Vietnamese forces, the Congress, and all the rest of it.
Well, I remember you were writing how the South Vietnamese economy in 1972 was equitable to South Korea in the 60s.
No, not the 60s.
Oh, no, no, the 60s was the takeoff period in South Vietnamend period.
It was a time of peace, and they'd had time
What I'm saying is that they built up, during the war, certain of the elements of what I call the preconditions for takeoff.
One education, which is very, very important.
They only had one institute of higherwell, they had no institute of higher learning in the South, under the French.
The only university was Hanoi, and they built this series of universities, technical schools, very high degree of literacy.
Secondly, agriculture.
They began to bring in chemical fertilizers, some of the new seeds, and an American woman in aid brought in the chicken revolution.
And then we sent out Stanford Research Institute to help them design a land reform program, which was instituted, and the tube got it through.
It was a very hard thing to do.
members of the Senate were mainly landlords.
But they didn't have a big feudal agriculture, but they did have some.
And so they had, then they had the other thing, a big infrastructure improvement.

So during the war, certain fundamental things were happening, which at a time of peace, might have permitted them, it might have, would have permitted them to go into takeoff, but you couldn't do it with the war going on.
But wasn't all that not so much due to the South Vietnamese government, but more to just Americans just pumping money into the economy?
If you don't have people who can do it, you're pushing on a string.
Do you ever think for a moment of how the South Vietnamese are doing in the United States?
Do you see how many are winning science prizes, valedictorians, or going to college?

You know, one of the things that really worries me about people, if we decided that we wanted to give up on them for whatever reasons we had a right to, and people will differ and argue about it for a long time, but you don't seem to realize what lies behind your questions.
A systematic picture which tends to blame their defeat on the Vietnamese.
They don't have nationalisms.
They ran away at some battle.
They didn't do anything for themselves.
All they did was get American money.
You've got a whole set of biases.
I don't think you've ever examined them.
Did you ever ask yourself what your general assumption is or your own view?
Your questions are allI've lived through this kind of questioning, and I don't mind it at all.
I'm not annoyed.

But I don't think your questions at all reflect any reading of what I've written about it, which is all right if you want to just try out your clich questions on these poor bastards of South Vietnamese who deserved everything they got, which is your attitude and the basis for your questions.
That's all right.
But one of the most fundamental things in social science and history, if you're ever going to do it, is to be conscious of your own biases.
And if you look in the back of this book, which I urge you to look at sometime, you'll find that I stated my own view of the U.S. national interest.
Why?
Because it, your assumptions control the questions you ask.
What data you regard as relevant, what data you regard as irrelevant.
And I don't sense that you've really given this any self-conscious thought and questioned yourself.
After all, you're a new generation.
And I don't know whether you're aware that President Carter and President Reagan have reaffirmed the relevance of the Southeast Asia Treaty to Thailand.
Southeast Asia has not gone away.
I think there's a fair chance there won't be a war out there.
But, you know, it's in your lifetime that this place is still alive, and you've got to make up your mind as to its meaning.
And I don't think you'll ever come to an understanding of that.
unless you ask yourself, where did I get my ideas?
What do I think?
Where have I picked this up?
Is that right?
And, well, carry on.
Go ahead with your questions.
But they're an extraordinarily systematic set of questions, but they have nothing to do with anything I've ever written.
Carry on.
What pacification programs do you believe were successful and which were failures, and why?
I don't think that you, in a pacification program,
I'm speaking of Phoenix, Hess, the PRU teams.
Well, I don't really know enough about them, but what I do know is two things.
One, what you call pacification was a very uneven process in different parts of the country, and it depended a lot on the local people, the quality of leadership, the quality of some of the advisors.
Two, I think that the overall picture that I have in here is pretty accurate, the statistical picture.
Well, I remember you were writing about how you thought pacification was doing a good job and was successful, but But what?
I don't remember you mentioning any specific programs.
You mentioned how Well, that's what I'm saying now.
What I'm saying is that this chart here of population status in South Vietnam
I think is pretty fair, you know, accurate.
Why do I think so?
Because in the periods where we know things went bad, take 1965, these data show quite clearly a gain in the VC area of control.
In this area of slow improvement in 1966,
It leveled off here.
We know that about this period, they began to come into the north, and it slowed up our progress.
We know there was a dip in Tet, much less than we thought at first, but there was a dip in Tet.
And we know that in the course of 68 to 69, they got badly rolled up, and their own evidence and everyone else's view, so that they were confined in this period pretty much to the
the peripheral frontier.
So I regard thisI think anybody who thinks he can measure that kind of thing in forty-odd provinces with great accuracy is kidding himself.
On the other hand, if you take this, and if you can see that when it goes bad, you know, it's reflected
And when things are going better, it's reflected.
When it goes bad, it's reflected.
In this period, when the VC were essentially washed out, it rolls up.
Now, even then, I wouldn't believe this measure by itself.
You've got to take everything that's quantitative, here's the ratio of enemy losses to ours, and see if it fits with everything else and if it fits with the qualitative evidence.
Now, we had some of the ablest young men in our country
Foreign service officers, AID officers, CIA officers, out in these villages, asked to read their reports.
And if you read enough of them, you know, the picture would be very uneven, but you'd get a sense of what, of which way it was moving.
And I think that's about the best you can do in a war of that kind, without a fixed front.
Now, a fixed front, you see it visually, like a football game.
But this was not that kind of war.
It did not have a fixed front.
all manner of quantitative and non-quantitative evidence to get a feel for which way it's drifting, and I think that picture is pretty accurate.
Did journalists use their influence to get Americans against the war effort, or in general, did the media affect the outcome of the war?
The outcome of the war is very hard.
I think that the reporting on the whole was not very good.
I think it was partly not very good for understandable reasons.
A lot of the people that were assigned out there had never dealt with a developing country before.
A lot of them never really got outside the Caravelle Hotel much.
When they did, they'd much rather go with a US unit than a South Vietnamese unit.
And for good reason, they spoke the language and it was safer.
And I don't hold that against them.
The big thing they did, of course, was grossly to misinterpret Tet and misreport it.
On the other hand, I don't think they deserve
Well, let me put it.
I think the media earned that.
You shouldn't expect them to report a war very well.
A war is a very hard thing to report.
It's an emotional thing.
And in a democracy, virtually all wars are going to be very, very divisive.
This Revolutionary War was terribly divisive.
The War of 1812
New England people were marching on Washington, trying to get out of the Union.
From Hartford, the Mexican War was extremely divisive, regionally.
Civil War, of course.
The Spanish-American War was very divisive.
First World War was divisive.
And we didn't get into the second.
We were so divided that the only reason we got into the Second World War is we got attacked at Pearl Harbor.
The Germans declared
And, you know, in the Korean War, Mr. Truman ended up with lower polls than Mr. Nixon when he left the White House.
So war is a dreadful thing.
And in a democracy, I'd expect it, especially if it runs, if it's all protracted, that it would be divisive.
So I'm not inclined to blame the press excessively.

I think they did a bad job and had some considerable influence on the view of Tet, but I think that President Johnson and our administration didn't explain before the event as much as we should have about Tet, which we knew was coming.
So, I mean, it's part of it, but I don't want to produce a, you know, I don't believe that somehow the press should be made a scapegoat

uh did the what was the role of the anti-war movement did that affect decision making as far as you want to keep your popularity up possibly and if you see these hundreds of thousands of kids protesting in front of the tv camera and then you're sitting down at your 5 30 dinner and then you see this too and then that makes you think did the anti-war movement possibly affect decision making as far as maybe
Let's speak of Tet.
Maybe after Tet, General Westmoreland requested 206,000 more troops, and he got, I believe, 50,000 or 80,000 more.
Well, he didn't get more troops.
First, because he didn't have M-16s, it turned out.
And I don't know how that- and it's a very amusing story, in a way, because Chew mobilized
a whole 150,000 or whatever it was there.
And the president said, well, if it was a choice between giving them 16 South Vietnamese and Americans, I know which way it was going.
Also, there were some financial considerations.
And also, by the time they came around to make the decision, the president made the decision before it got into the newspapers, it was palpable that
She was, the South Vietnamese, well, had been a real military victory on our side.
There was some ambiguity until we could establish, especially, it took a little while to establish what we'd lost in the countryside.
And it turned out we didn't lose anything because they were out of the countryside and South Vietnamese were out of the countryside and the people were just growing rice there.
But in any case, what was your question again?
Did the war or the anti-war movement?
The anti-war movement, I would say it's a hard question.
It did not affect any of the basic decisions because, see right down to Tet, 60% of the people defined themselves as hawks.
President Johnson was much more worried about the hawks than he was about the doves.
And what actually weakened the war effort was the defection of the hawks on their misinterpretation of Tet.
rather than the rise of the Doves.
But the reason I'm hesitant is that the overall decisions, I'd say no.
But as far as President Johnson is concerned, decisions in the war are concerned.
But as for individual people in the administration, I cannot vouch for their effects on individuals.
had no effect on me.
You talked about a lot how Let me tell you why.
I had thought I was luckier than most, in a peculiar sense, if I was going to get involved in this.
Because in the 1950s, after I'd done a study of the Soviet Union that turned out to be quite useful at the time of Stalin's
The government asked me to do a study of China and Asia.
And I said, well, I'd prove this could be done usefully, and let's get somebody else to do it.
Max Milliken and I had set up this Center for International Studies at MIT, but no one would touch it because of McCarthy and all that.
And so they came back to me, and my wife, who was very wise, suggested it be a good thing to do, and I did it.
And so I had a chance in tranquility to look very far back and very far forward.
and wrote two books, one called Prospects for Communist China and another American Policy in Asia.
So this whole array of issues that we were thrust into in the Kennedy administration were familiar to me, and I had a chance to quietly to think it through.
for a lot of people, they got hit like a blindside block, and they'd thought about arms control, or developing areas, or reform of NATO, or education, or civil rights, or whatever, all those.
But very few had given much thought to the strategic problems of Asia, or the future of Asia.
And in that sense, I was lucky, and I'd come to
serious conclusions, as I say, and in fact publish them with no mystery about my view.
So that when, you know, the confusions and pressures of the war and debates arose, I knew what I thought and why.
In that sense, more at peace than many of my colleagues who were very much, and understandably, torn up by all this.
You mentioned McCarthy and the Red Scare.
Did a lot of good people get taken out of the State Department because of that, in your opinion, especially possibly Southeast Asian experts?
Because a lot of people believe that we should have recognized mainland China by, say, 1955, 1956, that recognizing Taiwan as the leader of the great nation of that size was a mistake.
I don't think it had anything to do with anybody in the State Department.
Well, they've just said that a lot of people just did not know a lot about Vietnam.
I know.
I know that people say a lot of things, but there are a lot of people that did know a lot about Vietnam.
Well, our problem was not that we didn't know a lot about Vietnam.
We know a great deal.
Okay.
You mentioned that you all felt that Tet was about to happen, and I remember reading how you said you were
You'd wish you had asked President Johnson to speak more about it in the State of the Union Address.
Why, then, was the 716th Military Police Battalion the only American unit in Saigon attacked?
We had a tremendouswe'd pulled back a couple of divisions around Saigon.
They were wonderfully prepared for Tet.
The U.S. forces were absolutely geared up for Tet.
Well, we had a man who was in the 716th, and he was in Saigon.
Why don't you go and you read the evidence on it?
For goodness sakes, I mean, you get somebody to come in and you get one detainee.
Did you ever read Westmoreland's cables to President Johnson before Tet?
Do you know what President Johnson told his cabinet before Tet?
Well, I knew he knew it was going to happen and that he wanted to get everybody prepared and that Westmoreland was acting to get his forces ready for him.
And he did get them ready, and he called off the American forces, had the leave canceled.
they were pulled back around Saigon.
And, you know, there's a vast amount of evidence on this.
Okay.
What a mistake.
You know, if you have some guy who says something, then you better say, well, you know, the war's very, if you're aware in one place in the war, that's a very important place in the war.
But it doesn't mean that
A guy who's in some unit really knows where the other units are, what orders his commander's issued.
And those are things that can be found out and can be checked.
